report_labels.paradox_alert: [Warning] Logic paradox detected. Retesting is recommended.
no_match: Your tendencies are unique and do not align with standard historical models.

questions.text: Q1. In your view, what is the most legitimate source of power for an ideal leader?

options.text: A. Long-standing tradition and the continuity of family bloodlines (including ceremonial and ruling monarchs)
B. Extraordinary courage and an iron fist demonstrated during national turmoil or crisis
C. A professional elite group cultivated and selected through long-term consensus
D. Votes cast by citizens through independent competition within a legal framework

questions.text: Q2. When society faces fundamental disagreements, which decision-making mechanism do you trust most?

options.text: A. Final adjudication on specific issues directly by all citizens
B. Unified instructions from the sole leading body symbolizing national unity
C. Listening to recognized civil representatives while ensuring systemic stability
D. Mediation by traditional families or patriarchal authorities with deep roots

questions.text: Q3. Regarding 'Professionalism' vs. 'Participation' in governance, you lean towards:

options.text: A. Governance should be the sole responsibility of a professional, disciplined core committee
B. Governance should be open to all political views, ensuring competition even if the process is messy
C. Leaders should seek mandates directly from the people, bypassing complex bureaucratic intermediaries
D. Elections should serve as a ritual to demonstrate national unity and support for the status quo

questions.text: Q15. In your opinion, 'The Law' should be:

options.text: A. The supreme principle that rulers must absolutely obey (even if it reduces efficiency)
B. An effective tool for rulers to govern, adjustable according to needs
C. A contractual text resulting from compromises between the ruler and various elite factions
D. Subordinate to a higher national will or the leader's ultimate decision

questions.text: Q16. If the government tries to implement a beneficial policy but is blocked by a court on grounds of procedural unconstitutionality:

options.text: A. Legal procedures should yield to national interests; the policy should be enforced by bypassing obstacles
B. Law should be treated as a tool; the law should be amended to make the policy legal before implementation
C. The court's ruling must be respected, even if the policy fails or is delayed

questions.text: Q19. You believe that media reports critical of the government should:

options.text: A. Be strictly guided by the state to ensure a unified social will
B. Be allowed to exist, but face administrative restrictions on core decision-making issues
C. Be independent of executive power, serving as an external 'natural enemy' to authority

questions.text: Q40. If a system can bring continuous economic growth, would you permanently give up your right to political participation?

options.text: A. Yes, the outcome (growth and stability) is more important than the process
B. No, without procedural legitimacy, the distribution of outcomes is unreliable

X1Y1: Personal Seizure (X1) × No Constraint (Y1). Power is concentrated in one person, maintained by ideological mobilization and security apparatus.
X1Y2: Personal Seizure (X1) × Instrumental Constraint (Y2). Laws exist but are tools; opposition is selectively suppressed.
X2Y2: Elite Group Selection (X2) × Instrumental Constraint (Y2). Collective control by a small circle; procedures serve group interests.
X2Y2_bureaucracy: A single ruling entity governs through a rigorous bureaucratic hierarchy (X2) with administrative control (Y2).
X2Y3: Elite Group Selection (X2) × Weak Separation of Powers (Y3). Consensus reached through elite bargaining; limited judicial presence.
X2Y4: Elite Selection (X2) × Strong Constitutional Constraint (Y4). Governed by professional elites and strictly limited by an independent judiciary.
X3Y1: Hereditary Succession (X3) × No Constraint (Y1). The monarch's personal will is supreme; law and ritual serve royal power.
X3Y4: Hereditary Succession (X3) × Strong Separation of Powers and Bill of Rights (Y4). Ceremonial monarch; government is elected and constitutionally bound.
X4Y2: Non-competitive Elections (X4) × Instrumental Constraint (Y2). Controlled elections provide procedural symbolic legitimacy.
X5Y3: Limited Competitive Elections (X5) × Weak Separation of Powers (Y3). Unequal party competition; policy easily dominated by the executive.
X6Y4: Full Competitive Elections (X6) × Strong Rule of Law (Y4). Free and fair elections, independent judiciary, and protection of rights.
X6Y4_negotiation: Introduction of social partnership and negotiation mechanisms on top of representative democracy (X6/Y4).
X7Y2: Direct Mandate (X7) × Instrumental Constraint (Y2). Leaders bypass procedures using 'popular will' to strike at establishment elites.
X7Y3: Direct Mandate (X7) × Weak Separation of Powers (Y3). Frequent referendums prone to manipulation and emotional decision-making.
X7Y5: Direct Mandate (X7) × Double Constraint of Procedures and Issues (Y5). Complementary relationship between representation and direct participation.

X1Y4: Simultaneously demanding a strongman to break resistance (X1) and a legal system to lock down the strongman (Y4) is logically inconsistent.
X6Y1: Absolute popular will (X6) combined with zero constraint (Y1) leads to a rapid collapse into purges and chaos.
X7Y1: Popular will (X7) without institutional brakes (Y1) is a shortcut to autocracy.
